fr.sorbonne_u.components.endpoints

Class POJOEndPoint<I>

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sorbonne_u.components.AbstractEndPoint
      • fr.sorbonne_u.components.endpoints.EndPoint<I>
        • fr.sorbonne_u.components.endpoints.POJOEndPoint<I>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AbstractEndPointI, EndPointI<I>, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class POJOEndPoint<I>
extends EndPoint<I>
implements java.lang.Cloneable
    The class POJOEndPoint defines a plain old Java object (POJO) reference implementing in the Java sense the interface I as an end point.

    Description

    A POJO end point is an abstraction of a standard Java reference but conforming to the end point protocols, so this implementation merely uses the reference to the Java server object as the reference to be used by the client to call it. As an end point, it only adds the explicit knowledge of the implemented interface inherited from EndPoint<I>.

    This implementation is not thread safe.

    Implementation Invariants

     invariant       endPointURI != null && !endPointURI.isEmpty()

    Invariants

     invariant       GLOBAL_ENDPOINT_REFERENCES != null

    Created on : 2024-06-25

    Author:
    Jacques Malenfant

    • Field Detail

      • GLOBAL_ENDPOINT_REFERENCES

        protected static final java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> GLOBAL_ENDPOINT_REFERENCES
        map from end point URIs to Java object references to server objects; this map is neede to respect the same protocol as other end points i.e., using copyWithSharable to pass end points both to the server and the client sides and then initialiseServerSide before initialiseClientSide which must retrieve the Java server object reference.

      • endPointURI

        protected final java.lang.String endPointURI
        URI of the end point.

      • reference

        protected transient I reference
        direct reference to the POJO.

      • copyWithSharable

        public POJOEndPoint<I> copyWithSharable()
        return a copy of this POJO end point.

        Description

        As a POJO end point is meant to represent connections among entities that reside in the same address space, the reference to the server side is considered as sharable.

        By default, this implementation merely clone (i.e., shallow copy) the end point. If a subclass introduces non sharable elements, it will have to redefine the method to avoid copying these.

        Contract

         pre     true        // no more preconditions.
 post    return.getClientSideInterface().equals(getClientSideInterface()))
        Specified by:
        copyWithSharable in interface EndPointI<I>
        Returns:
        a duplicate of this end point except its transient information.
        See Also:
        EndPointI.copyWithSharable()
